abstract.para: &esxx; is a free, easy-to-install, easy-to-use, no-nonsense &es; application server, incorporating familar technologies such as &xml;, &xslt;, &sql;, &ldap; and Java into one single package.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: In the late 90's, I was involved in the development of a one of the first Web/&xml; application servers developed. During that time, we realized the benefits of using data-driven programming for server-based web applications. In this context, data-driven programming means that the data, that is to be returned as response to a request, is generated and then gradually refined until it reaches the user, most often in the form of an (X)HTML page, using plain &xml; as intermediate formats.

By focusing solely on what to present to the user in the logic stage and not how, the programmer can focus on what he or she is good at, and leave presentation and graphical design to those who knows better.
Six years later, after a period of not being involved with anything web related at all, I find that people are still mixing &html; and server-side code on a regular basis.
Worse yet, when looking around for a free, easy-to-use tool to drive a site I was planning, I found nothing that I liked. So, I rolled my own: &esxx;.

section.title: System requirements
section.para: &esxx; is a FastCGI appliaction, so if you're using Apache, make sure it's configured with mod_fastcgi enabled.
The application/octet-stream parser loads a resource as-is into a Java ByteBuffer object.

The image type of parses loads the specified resource as a Java BufferedImage object. The file types supported by &j2se; 6.0 are: image/bmp, image/gif, image/jpeg, image/png and , image/wbmp. Use image/* to automatically identify the image type.
When specifying a specific image type, the unofficial x-index parameter can be used to specify the index of the image, in case the file contains multiple images.

The text/html parser loads the resource as an &html; file, using the &html; parser , to transform the document into well-formed &xml;. The charset parameter can be used to specify the character set to be used. The result is an XML object.
The text/plain parser loads the resource as a plain String. The charset parameter can be used to specify the character set to be used.
The text/xml parser loads the resource as an &es; XML object. The document must be well-formed and if it has a DOCTYPE, external entities will be included as well.
text/x-sql is not supported as a parser. In &esxx;, it's only as query type for jdbc: URIs.
